Dear Ms. Gillies:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
7/26/2021-7/30/2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member shall not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker
for purposes of providing direct services in foster care,
independent living, adoption, or post adoption services or a
combination thereof.
One of seven caseload carrying staff was out of caseload compliance by 1 case.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of three open youth files reviewed contained one service plan that was
completed outside of the required timeframe by one day.
R 400.12604 Orientation and application.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application is
provided. The orientation shall include a review of all of the
following:
(a) Program statement, policies, and procedures.
4

Two of three files reviewed contained documentation that the application was
provided and completed prior to the orientation occurring.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/30/2019 INTERIM, CAP Approved 8/30/2019
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Three of three adoption evaluations reviewed were completed outside of the
required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

An agency shall document that an orientation for the
adoptive parents was provided before it is determined they
are suitable parent to an adopted child.

provided to adoptive parents.

DHHS Policy Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
ADM 330 –P. 1
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report. The
5

adoption worker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child during each quarter prior to the adoption
supervision period for the purpose of completing the DHHS-614.
The child assessment may serve as the initial quarterly report if
it is completed within the required quarterly reporting period and
attached to the DHHS-614 form.
Two of six Adoption Assessment/Placement case files reviewed did not have the
quarterly adoption progress report signed and/or completed in the required time
frame.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/19/2020 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 6/25/2020
7/30/2019 INTERIM, CAP Approved 8/30/2019
DHHS Policy CASE ACCEPTANCE AND ASSIGNMENT
ADM 210, page 4
Within seven working days of receipt of the adoption
referral from foster care, the adoption referral must be
accepted or rejected. Rejection of a referral must include a
detailed explanation of the reason for rejection. If the
referral is accepted, the adoption supervisor must assign
the case to an adoption worker within three working days
to initiate the DHHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment and
identify or recruit a qualified family for adoption.
One of six files reviewed was not in compliance with this requirement as the case
was referred on 3/10/21 and accepted on 3/29/21
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/30/2019 INTERIM, CAP Approved 8/30/2019

acceptance

FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
P. 1
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business days
of change in caseworker and/or organization.
One of seven total foster care files reviewed (3 open, 4 closed) did not contain action
summaries complete as required. One file had a closing action summary that was
completed outside of the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-09C & 722-03
5/19/2020 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 6/25/2020
7/30/2019 INTERIM, CAP Approved 8/30/2019
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
7

Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Two of three open case files reviewed did not meet the FTM policy requirements for
service plan development. One file documented an FTM occurring after the service
plan completion and the other did not have documentation of an FTM for service
plan development

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ADM 980 ADOPTION CLOSING SUMMARY
The purpose of the closing summary is to provide a concise
summary of the child’s adoption. The closing summary should
include a description of events related to the adoption that have
not been previously addressed in the DHS-614, Quarterly
Adoption Progress Reports. A copy of the closing summary
must be sent within 14 calendar days of the adoption finalization
date to the foster care worker and the Department of Health and
Services (DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of service
cases for inclusion in the child’s permanent record. The DHS-
222, Adoption Closing Summary must be used for this purpose.
8

One of six adoption files reviewed contained an adoption closing summary that was
completed 23 days after finalization.
SRM 103 In-Service Training
MDHHS and private caseload-carrying staff and specialized
support staff must complete 32 hours of in-service training each
calendar year.
One of seven caseload carrying staff did not have the required training hours
documented. This staff member only had 13 of the required 32 hours.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 One foster home evaluation only included the months that emergency
procedures were practiced, not the dates. It was recommended the specific
date be included.
 One foster home file had the incorrect dates for the completed CPR/First Aid
training documented within the training hyperlink and on the uploaded training
log. It was recommended dates be consistent.
 When secondary caregivers are present during foster home visits, agency
was informed to document each participant and make note of their presence
in the case contact.
 One adoptive family evaluation described the weapons in the home as
“locked up” but did not provide a description of how they were secured.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not in need of consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency is not compliance with the following as noted within the violations
in this report:
5/19/2020 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 6/25/2020
Chief Administrator Assessment – I reviewed the Chief Administrator Assessment
in which the identified areas of concern aligned with the findings of this inspection.
9

CHRI - On 7/30/2021 I virtually viewed the storage of the key and the locked storage
area for CHRI information. I also viewed the dissemination and destruction logs
stored in this secure area.
Other Document Review - On 7/26/2021 I reviewed the agency’s organization
chart, updated policies, completed financial audit, and case ratios. Staffing changes
throughout the year have resulted in one staff member currently being out of
caseload compliance, which will be rectified when another staff member completes
CWTI Training. I also discussed the agency’s MMR and AFPRR progress
throughout the year.
Staff Interviews – The staff reported that despite several staffing changes, they
have felt supported by leadership and co-workers. No concerns were identified
during the interviews.
VII. ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
